{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2016}} '''Dog-whistle politics''' is political messaging employing coded language that appears to mean one thing to the general population but has an additional, different, or more specific resonance for a targeted subgroup. The analogy is to a [[dog whistle]], whose [[Ultrasound|ultrasonic]] whistling sound is heard by dogs but inaudible to humans. The term can be distinguished from "[[Code word (figure of speech)|code words]]" used in some specialist professions, in that dog-whistling is specific to the political realm. The messaging referred to as the dog-whistle has an understandable meaning for a general audience, rather than being incomprehensible. ==Origin and meaning== According to [[William Safire]], the term "dog whistle" in reference to politics may have been derived from its use in the field of [[opinion poll]]ing. Safire quotes Richard Morin, director of polling for ''[[The Washington Post]]'', as writing in 1988,
subtle changes in question-wording sometimes produce remarkably different results... researchers call this the 'Dog Whistle Effect': Respondents hear something in the question that researchers do not{{cite book |last=Safire |first=William |date=2008 |title=Safire's political dictionary |edition=Rev. |location=New York |publisher=Oxford University Press |page=190 |isbn=0-19-534334-4}}
and speculates that campaign workers adapted the phrase from political pollsters. In her 2006 book, ''Voting for Jesus: Christianity and Politics in Australia'', academic [[Amanda Lohrey]] writes that the goal of the dog-whistle is to appeal to the greatest possible number of electors while alienating the smallest possible number. She uses as an example Australian politicians using broadly appealing words such as "family" and "values", which have extra resonance for Christians, while avoiding overt Christian moralizing that might be a turn-off for non-Christian voters.{{cite book|last=Lohrey|first=Amanda|title=Voting for Jesus: Christianity and Politics in Australia|year=2006|publisher=Black Inc.|location=Melbourne, Vic.|isbn=1-86395-230-6|pages=48–58}} Australian political theorist [[Robert E. Goodin]] argues that the problem with dog-whistling is that it undermines democracy, because if voters have different understandings of what they were supporting during a campaign, the fact that they were seeming to support the same thing is "democratically meaningless" and does not give the dog-whistler a [[Mandate (politics)|policy mandate]].{{cite book|last=Goodin|first=Robert E.|title=Innovating Democracy: Democratic Theory and Practice after the Deliberative Turn|year=2008|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=0-19-954794-7|pages=224–228|edition=Repr.}} ==History and usage== ===Australia=== The term was first picked up in [[Australian politics]] in the mid-1990s, and was frequently applied to the political campaigning of [[John Howard]].Grant Barrett, ''The official dictionary of unofficial English'', McGraw-Hill Professional, 2006, p. 90 Throughout [[Howard Government|his 11 years]] as [[Prime Minister of Australia|Australian prime minister]] and particularly in his fourth term, Howard was accused of communicating messages appealing to anxious Australian voters using code words such as "un-Australian", "mainstream", and "illegals".{{cite book|last=Soutphommasane|first=Tim|title=Reclaiming patriotism: nation-building for Australian progressives|year=2009|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Melbourne|isbn=0-521-13472-2|pages=19–20}}{{cite book|last=Gelber|first=Katharine|title=Speech matters: getting free speech right|publisher=University of Queensland Press|location=St Lucia, Qld.|isbn=0-7022-3873-2|pages=end-notes|edition=1st}} One notable example was the Howard government's message on refugee arrivals. The Howard government's tough stance on refugee arrivals was popular with voters, but the government was accused of using the issue to additionally send veiled messages of support to voters with racist leanings,{{cite book|last= Garran|first=Robert|title=True believer: John Howard, George Bush and the American alliance|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lKDKREH24PsC|year=2004|publisher=Allen & Unwin|isbn=978-1-74114-418-5|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=lKDKREH24PsC&pg=PA18 18]}} while maintaining [[plausible deniability]] by avoiding overtly racist language.Josh Fear, ''[https://www.tai.org.au/documents/downloads/DP96.pdf Under the Radar: Dog-whistle politics in Australia]'', [[The Australia Institute]], September 2007 Another example is the publicity of the [[Australian citizenship test]] in 2007. It has been argued that the test may appear reasonable at face value, but is really intended to appeal to those opposing immigration from particular geographic regions.{{cite news | author=Editorial | url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/editorial/no-question-about-a-citizenship-test/2006/12/12/1165685675052.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=No question about a citizenship test | date=December 13, 2006 |accessdate=July 17, 2014}} ===Canada=== During the [[Canadian federal election, 2015|2015 Canadian federal election]], the [[Conservative Party of Canada|Conservative party]] led by incumbent Prime Minister [[Stephen Harper]] was accused of communicating 'code' words in a debate to appeal to his party's base supporters. Midway through the election campaign the Conservative Party hired Australian political strategist [[Lynton Crosby]] as a political adviser when they fell to third place in the polls behind the [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal Party]] and the [[New Democratic Party]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/conservatives-hire-high-profile-australian-strategist-to-reboot-campaign/article26315392/|title=Controversial Australian strategist to help with Tories' campaign|first=Steven|last=Chase|date=11 September 2015|accessdate=6 May 2016}} During a televised election debate Stephen Harper, while discussing the government's controversial decision to remove certain immigrants and refugee claimants from accessing Canada's health care system made reference to '[[Old Stock Canadians]]' as being in support of the government's position. Opposition leader reacted calling his words racist and divisive.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/harper-old-stock-canadians-debate-1.3233615|title=Harper's 'old-stock Canadians' line is part deliberate strategy: pollster|date=18 September 2015|accessdate=6 May 2016}} ===France=== In France, the phrase "a band of youths" in Paris tends to mean North African descent.{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Reflections-Revolution-Europe-Immigration-Islam/dp/0307276759|date=2009|page=14|title=Reflections on the Revolution In Europe|first=Christopher|last=Caldwell|access-date=February 14, 2018}} ===United Kingdom=== [[Lynton Crosby]], who had previously managed [[John Howard]]'s four election campaigns in Australia, worked as a [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] adviser during the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|2005 UK general election]], and the term was introduced to British political discussion at this time. In what Goodin calls "the classic case" of dog-whistling,{{cite book|last=Goodin|first=Robert E.|title=Innovating democracy: democratic theory and practice after the deliberative turn|year=2008|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=0-19-954794-7|pages=226|edition=Repr.}} Crosby created a campaign for the Conservatives with the slogan "Are you thinking what we're thinking?": a series of posters, billboards, TV commercials and direct mail pieces with messages like "It's not racist to impose limits on immigration" and "how would you feel if a bloke on early release attacked your daughter?"{{cite book|last=Lees-Marshment|first=Jennifer|title=Political marketing: principles and applications|year=2009|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=0-415-43128-X|pages=169}} focused on controversial issues like unsanitary hospitals, land grabs by gypsies and restraints on police behaviour.{{cite news|last=McCallister|first=J.F.O.|title=Whistling In the Dark?|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1044651,00.html|accessdate=9 September 2012|newspaper=Time |date=3 April 2005}}{{cite book|last=Seawright|first=David|title=The British Conservative Party and one nation politics|year=2007|publisher=Continuum|location=London|isbn=0-8264-8974-5|pages=134}} Labour MP [[Diane Abbott]] described the 2013 [["Go Home" vans]] advertising campaign by the British [[Home Office]] as an example of dog-whistle politics.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/jul/26/go-home-ad-campaign-court-challenge|title='Go home' ad campaign targeting illegal immigrants faces court challenge|last=Taylor|first=Matthew|last2=Gidda|first2=Mirren|date=2013-07-26|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-06-07|last3=Syal|first3=Rajeev}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/governments-go-home-vans-backed-by-immigration-minister-mark-harper-8889358.html|title=Government's 'Go home' vans backed by Immigration Minister Mark Harper|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-06-07|language=en-GB|first=James|last=Legge|date=18 October 2013}} In April 2016 [[Mayor of London]] and Conservative [[Member of parliament#United Kingdom|MP]] [[Boris Johnson]] was accused of "dog whistle racism" by [[Shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer]] and [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] MP [[John McDonnell (politician)|John McDonnell]] when Johnson suggested [[President of the United States|US President]] [[Barack Obama]] held a grudge against the United Kingdom due to his "ancestral dislike of the [[British Empire]]" as a result of his "part-Kenyan" heritage after Obama expressed his support for the UK to vote to remain in the [[European Union]] ahead of the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|UK's referendum on EU membership]].{{cite tweet |author= [[John McDonnell (politician)|John McDonnell]] |user= johnmcdonnellMP|number= 723481596096090112 |date= 22 April 2016 |title= Mask slips again. Boris part-Kenyan Obama comment is yet another example of dog whistle racism from senior Tories. He should withdraw it. |access-date= {{date}} }}{{cite news |last=Cowburn |first=Ashley |date=22 April 2016 |title=Boris Johnson accused of ‘dog whistle racism’ over controversial Barack Obama Kenya remarks |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/boris-johnson-barack-obama-kenya-remarks-accused-dog-whistle-racism-john-mcdonnell-labour-a6996286.html |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |access-date=24 April 2016}} In the [[2016 London Mayoral Election]], Conservative candidate [[Zac Goldsmith]] was accused of running a dog-whistle campaign against Labour's [[Sadiq Khan]], playing on Khan's Muslim faith by suggesting he would target Hindus and Sikhs with a "jewellery tax" and attempting to link him to extremists.{{cite web |date=15 March 2016 |title= The deafening dogwhistle of Zac Goldsmith’s London mayoral campaign leaflets |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/media/2016/03/deafening-dogwhistle-zac-goldsmith-s-london-mayoral-campaign-leaflets |publisher = [[New Statesman]]}}{{cite web |last=Bienkov |first=Adam |date=4 October 2016 |title=Ethnic minority Tories say Zac Goldsmith's dog-whistle campaign badly damaged party |url=http://www.politics.co.uk/blogs/2016/10/04/ethnic-minority-tories-zac-goldsmith-damaged-party}} ===United States=== The phrase "[[states' rights]]", literally referring to powers of individual state governments in the United States, was described in 2007 by David Greenberg in ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' as "code words" for institutionalized segregation and racism.{{cite web | url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/history_lesson/2007/11/dogwhistling_dixie.html | title=Dog-Whistling Dixie. When Reagan said "states' rights," he was talking about race | publisher=Slate | date=Nov 20, 2007 | accessdate=May 21, 2012 | author=Greenberg, David}} ''States rights'' was the banner under which groups like the [[Defenders of State Sovereignty and Individual Liberties]] argued in 1955 against school desegregation.{{cite web|title=A Plan for Virginia Presented to the People of the Commonwealth by the Defenders of State Sovereignty and Individual Liberties|url=http://dc.lib.odu.edu/cdm/ref/collection/npsdp/id/1149|publisher=Defenders of State Sovereignty and Individual Liberties|accessdate=30 August 2017|date=June 8, 1955}} In 1981, former [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] strategist [[Lee Atwater]], when giving an anonymous interview discussing Nixon's [[Southern Strategy]], said:{{citation |author=Lamis, Alexander P. |date=1990 |title=The Two Party South |work=[[Oxford University Press]]|display-authors=etal}}{{citation |author=[[Bob Herbert|Herbert, Bob]] |date=October 6, 2005 |accessdate=February 5, 2016 |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C04E6DF1E30F935A35753C1A9639C8B63 |title=Impossible, Ridiculous, Repugnant |work=[[The New York Times]]}}{{YouTube|id=X_8E3ENrKrQ|title=Exclusive: Lee Atwater's Infamous 1981 Interview on the Southern Strategy}} {{quote|Y'all don't quote me on this. You start out in 1954 by saying, "[[Nigger]], nigger, nigger." By 1968, you can't say "nigger" — that hurts you. Backfires. So you say stuff like [[forced busing]], states' rights and all that stuff. You're getting so abstract now [that] you're talking about cutting taxes, and all these things you're talking about are totally economic things and a byproduct of them is [that] blacks get hurt worse than whites. And subconsciously maybe that is part of it. I'm not saying that. But I'm saying that if it is getting that abstract, and that coded, that we are doing away with the racial problem one way or the other. You follow me — because obviously sitting around saying, "We want to cut this," is much more abstract than even the busing thing, and a hell of a lot more abstract than "Nigger, nigger."|Lee Atwater, Republican Party strategist in an anonymous interview in 1981}} Atwater was contrasting this with [[Ronald Reagan]]'s campaign, which he felt "was devoid of any kind of racism, any kind of reference." However, others like U.S. law professor and author of the 2014 book ''Dog Whistle Politics'' [[Ian Haney-López]] described Reagan as "blowing a dog whistle" when the candidate told stories about "[[Cadillac]]-driving '[[welfare queen]]s' and 'strapping young bucks' buying T-bone steaks with [[Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program|food stamps]]" while he was campaigning for the presidency.{{cite book |last=Haney López |first=Ian |date=2014 |title=Dog Whistle Politics: How Coded Racial Appeals Have Reinvented Racism and Wrecked the Middle Class |location=New York |publisher=Oxford University Press |page=4 |isbn=978-0-19-996427-7}}[http://billmoyers.com/episode/ian-haney-lopez-on-the-dog-whistle-politics-of-race/ Full Show: Ian Haney López on the Dog Whistle Politics of Race, Part I]. ''[[Moyers & Company]]'', February 28, 2014.{{cite web | url=http://bpr.berkeley.edu/2015/11/09/a-coded-political-mantra/ | title=A Coded Political Mantra | publisher=Berkeley Political Review: UC Berkeley’s Only Nonpartisan Political Magazine | date=November 9, 2015 | accessdate=February 5, 2016 | author=Yao, Kevin}} He argues that such rhetoric pushes middle-class white Americans to vote against their economic self-interest in order to punish "undeserving minorities" who, they believe, are receiving too much public assistance at their expense. According to López, conservative middle-class whites, convinced by powerful economic interests that minorities are the enemy, supported politicians who promised to curb illegal immigration and crack down on crime but inadvertently also voted for policies that favor the extremely rich, such as slashing taxes for top income brackets, giving corporations more regulatory control over industry and financial markets, [[union busting]], cutting pensions for future public employees, reducing funding for public schools, and retrenching the social welfare state. He argues that these same voters cannot link rising inequality which has impacted their lives to the policy agendas they support, which resulted in a massive transfer of wealth to the top 1% of the population since the 1980s.[http://billmoyers.com/episode/ian-haney-lopez-on-the-dog-whistle-politics-of-race/ Full Show: Ian Haney López on the Dog Whistle Politics of Race, Part I]. ''[[Moyers & Company]]'', February 28, 2014. ''[https://global.oup.com/academic/product/dog-whistle-politics-9780199964277?cc=us&lang=en& Dog Whistle Politics: How Coded Racial Appeals Have Reinvented Racism and Wrecked the Middle Class] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218104049/https://global.oup.com/academic/product/dog-whistle-politics-9780199964277?cc=us&lang=en& |date=December 18, 2014 }}''. [[Oxford University Press]], 2014. {{ISBN|0-19-996427-0}} Journalist [[Craig Unger]] wrote that President [[George W. Bush]] and [[Karl Rove]] used coded "dog-whistle" language in political campaigning, delivering one message to the overall electorate while at the same time delivering quite a different message to a targeted [[Evangelicalism|evangelical Christian]] political base.{{cite book|last=Unger|first=Craig |title=The Fall of the House of Bush: The Untold Story of How a Band of True Believers Seized the Executive Branch, Started the Iraq War, and Still Imperils America's Future|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pSQJLqms8CcC|year=2007|publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]]|isbn=978-0-7432-8075-4|chapter=11. Dog Whistle Politics|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=pSQJLqms8CcC&pg=PA159|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=pSQJLqms8CcC&pg=PA172 172–173]}} [[William Safire]], in ''Safire's Political Dictionary'', offered the example of Bush's criticism during the [[United States presidential election, 2004|2004 presidential campaign]] of the [[U.S. Supreme Court|U.S. Supreme Court's]] 1857 [[Dred Scott v. Sandford|Dred Scott]] decision denying the [[Citizenship in the United States|U. S. citizenship]] of any [[African American]]. To most listeners the criticism seemed innocuous, Safire wrote, but "sharp-eared observers" understood the remark to be a pointed reminder that Supreme Court decisions can be reversed, and a signal that, if re-elected, Bush might nominate to the Supreme Court a justice who would overturn ''[[Roe v. Wade]]''. This view is echoed in a 2004 ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' article by Peter Wallsten.{{cite web | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/oct/13/nation/na-dred13 | title=Abortion Foes Call Bush's Dred Scott Reference Perfectly Clear | newspaper=Los Angeles Times| date=October 13, 2004 | accessdate=November 19, 2013 | author=Wallsten, Peter}} During the [[Democratic Party presidential primaries, 2008|2008 Democratic primaries]], several writers{{Who|date=October 2018}} criticized [[Hillary Clinton]]'s campaign's reliance on code words and innuendo seemingly designed to frame Barack Obama's race as problematic, saying Obama was characterized by the Clinton campaign and its prominent supporters as anti-white due to his association with Reverend [[Jeremiah Wright]], as able to attract only black votes, as anti-patriotic, a drug user, possibly a drug seller, and married to an angry, ungrateful black woman.{{cite book|last=Logan|first=Enid Lynette|title="At this defining moment": Barack Obama's presidential candidacy and the new politics of race|publisher=New York University Press|location=New York|isbn=0-8147-5298-5|pages=62}} In 2012, journalist [[Soledad O'Brien]] used the phrase "dog whistle" to describe [[Tea Party Express]] representative [[Amy Kremer]]'s accusation that President [[Barack Obama]] "does not love America".{{cite web | url=http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2012/09/04/cnns-soledad-obrien-confronts-tea-party-express-spokeswoman/ | title=CNN's Soledad O'Brien confronts Tea Party Express spokeswoman over 'very odd comment' | publisher=The Raw Story| date=September 4, 2012 | accessdate=September 7, 2012 | author=Dolan, Eric W.}} Also in that election cycle, Obama's campaign ran an ad that said [[Mitt Romney]] was "not one of us".{{YouTube|id=Mgiuq2uR6LA|title=Made in Ohio - Obama for America TV Ad}} The ad, which ''Washington Post'' journalist [[Karen Tumulty]] said "echoes a slogan that has been used as a racial code over at least the past half-century",{{cite news |author=Karen Tumulty |author-link=Karen Tumulty |date=October 22, 2012 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/decision2012/obama-mitt-romney-not-one-of-us/2012/10/22/e78714ba-1bb3-11e2-9cd5-b55c38388962_story.html |title=Obama's 'not one of us' attack on Romney echoes racial code |newspaper=Washington Post}} ran in Ohio, a state that is only 0.52% [[Mormon]].[[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints membership statistics (United States)]] During the [[United States Senate Republican primary election in Mississippi, 2014|2014 Republican senate primary in Mississippi]], a scandal emerged with politicians{{Who|date=October 2018}} accused of attempting to influence the public by using such "[[Code word (figure of speech)|code words]]" as "food stamps".{{cite web|last=Hall |first=Sam |url=http://www.clarionledger.com/story/dailyledes/2014/08/04/democrat-kkk-radio-ads/13584097/ |title=Harris denies anyone tied to Cochran involved in KKK ads |publisher=ClarionLedger.Com |date=August 5, 2014 |accessdate=August 7, 2014}}{{cite web|last=Fund |first=John |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/381187/flier-got-thad-cochran-elected-john-fund |title=The Flier That Got Thad Cochran Elected? |publisher=National Review |date=June 25, 2014 |accessdate=August 18, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2014/06/27/article-2672565-1F31B99200000578-214_306x509.jpg |title=The Tea Party Intends to prevent you from VOTING }}{{cite web|url=http://dailycaller.com/2014/08/06/why-im-moving-to-censure-henry-barbour-in-the-rnc-over-race-baiting-ads/|title=Why I’m Moving To Censure Henry Barbour In The RNC Over Race-Baiting Ads|publisher=''Daily Caller'' |date=8 August 2014|accessdate=22 August 2014}} Senator [[Ted Cruz]] called for an investigation,{{cite web|url=http://www.marklevinshow.com/common/page.php?pt=Ted+Cruz%3A+We+Need+An+Investigation+Into+the+Mississippi+Race&id=10103|title=Ted Cruz: We Need An Investigation Into the Mississippi Race|publisher=''The Mark Levin Show'' |date=July 7, 2014|accessdate=August 29, 2014}} saying that "the ads they ran were racially-charged false attacks".{{cite web|last=Sullivan |first=Sean |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2014/07/07/ted-cruz-slams-d-c-machine-over-mississippi-runoff-wants-voter-fraud-investigation/ |title=Ted Cruz slams ‘D.C. machine’ over Mississippi runoff, wants voter-fraud investigation |publisher=Washington Post |date=July 7, 2014 |accessdate=August 27, 2014}} During the 2016 presidential election campaign and during his presidency, [[Donald Trump]] was accused of using racial "dog whistling" techniques.{{cite web|first=Eli | last=Stokols|title=Jeb: Trump using racial 'dog whistle' | url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/09/bush-trump-dog-whistle-213334 | date=September 3, 2015 | access-date=May 1, 2017 | newspaper=Politico}}{{cite web|first=Cheryl | last=Greenberg | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/posteverything/wp/2016/10/26/donald-trumps-conspiracy-theories-sound-anti-semitic-does-he-even-realize-it/ | title=Donald Trump’s conspiracy theories sound anti-Semitic. Does he even realize it? | newspaper=Washington Post | date=October 26, 2016 | access-date=May 1, 2017}}{{cite web | last=Bernstein | first=David | newspaper=Washington Post | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2017/03/20/on-anti-semitism-and-dog-whistles/|title=On anti-Semitism and dog whistles| date=March 20, 2017 | access-date=May 1, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/politics/trailguide/la-na-trailguide-updates-condemning-trump-s-dog-whistle-1478205426-htmlstory.html|title=Condemning Trump's 'dog-whistle' campaign, Clinton cites endorsement in KKK newspaper | newspaper=Los Angeles Times |first=Michael|last=Memoli | date=Nov 3, 2016 | access-date=May 1, 2017}}{{cite news | title=Trump’s white-nationalist dog whistles in Warsaw | newspaper=Washington Post | author=Capehart, Jonathan | date=July 6, 2017 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-partisan/wp/2017/07/06/trumps-white-nationalist-dog-whistles-in-warsaw/}} ==See also== *[[Aesopian language]] *[[Code word (figure of speech)]] *[[Framing (social sciences)]] *[[Loaded language]] *[[Political correctness]] *[[Shibboleth]] *[[Southern strategy]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *"[https://web.archive.org/web/20060926182516/http://agonist.org/ian_welsh/20060925/just_a_comma_dog_whistle_politics Just a Comma]" by Ian Welsh at The Agonist, September 25, 2006 *"[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/10/04/AR2006100401707.html 'Just a Comma' Becomes Part of Iraq Debate]" by Peter Baker, ''The Washington Post'', Thursday, October 5, 2006, page A19 *[http://www.doubletongued.org/index.php/dictionary/dog_whistle_politics/ Etymology] from the Double-Tongued Dictionary *[http://billmoyers.com/episode/ian-haney-lopez-on-the-dog-whistle-politics-of-race/ Full Show: Ian Haney López on the Dog Whistle Politics of Race, Part I]. [[File:Myk Erbsenstreuling.jpg|thumb|Ectomycorrhizas and short-distance extramatrical mycelium]] '''Ectomycorrhizal extramatrical mycelium''' (also known as extraradical mycelium) is the collection of filamentous [[fungal]] hyphae emanating from [[ectomycorrhizas]]. It may be composed of fine, [[hydrophilic]] hypha which branches frequently to explore and exploit the soil matrix or may aggregate to form [[rhizomorphs]]; highly differentiated, [[hydrophobic]], enduring, transport structures.
== Characteristics ==
[[File:Mycorhizes-01.jpg|thumbnail|left|Ectomycorrhizas on ''Picea glauca'' roots surrounded by extramatrical mycelium]]
=== Overview ===
Apart from [[mycorrhizas]], extramatrical mycelium is the primary vegetative body of ectomycorrhizal fungi. It is the location of [[mineral]] acquisition,<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Landeweert R, Hoffland E, Finlay RD, Kuyper TW, van Breemen N |title=Linking plants to rocks: ectomycorrhizal fungi mobilize nutrients from minerals.|journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution|year=2001|volume=16|issue=5|pages=248–254|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S016953470102122X|doi=10.1016/S0169-5347(01)02122-X|pmid=11301154}}</ref> [[enzyme]] production,<ref name="TedersooNaadel2012">{{cite journal|last1=Tedersoo|first1=Leho|last2=Naadel|first2=Triin|last3=Bahram|first3=Mohammad|last4=Pritsch|first4=Karin|last5=Buegger|first5=Franz|last6=Leal|first6=Miguel|last7=Kõljalg|first7=Urmas|last8=Põldmaa|first8=Kadri|title=Enzymatic activities and stable isotope patterns of ectomycorrhizal fungi in relation to phylogeny and exploration types in an afrotropical rain forest|journal=New Phytologist|volume=195|issue=4|year=2012|pages=832–843|issn=0028-646X|doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2012.04217.x|pmid=22758212}}</ref> and a key means of colonizing new root tips.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Anderson|first=I.C.|author2=Cairney, J. W. G.|title=Ectomycorrhizal fungi: exploring the mycelial frontier.|journal=FEMS Microbiology Reviews|year=2007|volume=31|issue=4|pages=388–406|doi=10.1111/j.1574-6976.2007.00073.x}}</ref> Extramatrical mycelium facilitates the movement of [[carbon]] into the [[rhizosphere]],<ref name="Högberg 2002 791–795">{{cite journal|last=Högberg|first=M.N.|author2=Högberg, P.|title=Extramatrical ectomycorrhizal mycelium contributes one-third of microbial biomass and produces, together with associated roots, half the dissolved organic carbon in a forest soil.|journal=New Phytologist|year=2002|volume=154|issue=3|pages=791–795|doi=10.1046/j.1469-8137.2002.00417.x}}</ref> moves carbon and nutrients between hosts <ref>{{cite journal|last=Selosse|first=M.A.|author2=Richard, F. |author3=He, X. |author4=Simard, S. W. |title=Mycorrhizal networks: des liaisons dangereuses?|journal=Ecology and Evolution.|year=2006|doi=10.1016/j.tree.2006.07.003 |pmid=16843567 |volume=21 |issue=11 |pages=621–8}}</ref> and is an important food source for [[invertebrates]].<ref name="Pollierer 2007 729–36">{{cite journal|last=Pollierer|first=M.M.|author2=Langel, R. |author3=Körner, C. |author4=Maraun, M. |author5=Scheu, S. |title=The underestimated importance of belowground carbon input for forest soil animal food webs.|journal=Ecology Letters|year=2007|volume=10|issue=8|pages=729–36|doi=10.1111/j.1461-0248.2007.01064.x}}</ref>
=== Exploration type ===
The mycelial growth pattern, extent of biomass accumulation, and the presence or absence of [[rhizomorphs]] are used to classify fungi by exploration type. Agerer first proposed the designation of exploration types in 2001,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Agerer|first=R.|title=Exploration types of ectomycorrhizae A proposal to classify ectomycorrhizal mycelial systems according to their patterns of differentiation and putative ecological importance|journal=Mycorrhiza|year=2001|volume=11|pages=107–114|doi=10.1007/s005720100108 }}</ref> and the concept has since been widely employed in studies of ectomycorrhizal [[ecology]]. Four exploration types are commonly recognized: Contact, Short-distance, Medium-distance and Long-distance.
''Contact'' exploration types possess a predominantly smooth mantle and lack rhizomorphs with ectomycorrhizas in close contact with the surrounding [[substrate (biology)|substrate]]. ''Short-distance'' exploration types also lack rhizomorphs but the mantle is surrounded by frequent projections of hyphae, which emanate a short distance into the surrounding substrate. Most ectomycorrhizal [[ascomycetes]] are included in this group. ''Medium-distance'' exploration types are further divided into three subtypes defined by the growth range and differentiation of its rhizomorphs. ''Medium-distance Fringe'' form interconnected hyphal networks with rhizomorphs that divide and fuse repeatedly. ''Medium-distance Mat'' types form dense hyphal mats which aggregate into a homogeneous mass. Finally, the ''Medium-distance Smooth'' sub-type has rhizomorphs with smooth mantles and margins. [[File:HYPHAE.png|thumbnail|right|Fungal Hyphae Cells 1- Hyphal wall 2- Septum 3- Mitochondrion 4- Vacuole 5- Ergosterol crystal 6- Ribosome 7- Nucleus 8- Endoplasmic reticulum 9- Lipid body 10- Plasma membrane 11- Spitzenkörper/growth tip and vesicles 12- Golgi apparatus]] ''Long-distance'' exploration types are highly differentiated, forming rhizomorphs that contain hollow vessel-like transport tubes. Long distance types are associated with increased levels of organic nitrogen uptake compared to other exploration types and are thought to be less competitive in disturbed systems in contrast to short distance types which are able to regenerate more efficiently after a [[Disturbance (ecology)|disturbance event]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lilleskov|first=E. A|author2=Hobbie, E. A. |author3=Horton, T. R. |title=Conservation of ectomycorrhizal fungi: exploring the linkages between functional and taxonomic responses to anthropogenic N deposition. Fungal Ecology|journal=Fungal Ecology|year=2011|volume=4|issue=2|pages=174–183|doi=10.1016/j.funeco.2010.09.008}}</ref>
Exploration type is primarily consistent within a given [[Lineage (evolution)|lineage]]. However, some fungal genera which contain a large number of [[species]] have a great diversity of extramatrical hyphal morphology and are known to contain more than one exploration type.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Agerer|first=R.|title=Fungal relationships and structural identity of their ectomycorrhizae|journal=Mycological Progress|year=2006|volume=5|issue=2|pages=67–107|doi=10.1007/s11557-006-0505-x}}</ref> Because of this, extrapolating exploration type to species known only by lineage is difficult.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Tedersoo|first=L.|author2=Smith, M. E|title=Lineages of ectomycorrhizal fungi revisited: Foraging strategies and novel lineages revealed by sequences from belowground.|journal=Fungal Biology Reviews|year=2013|volume=27|issue=3–4|pages=83–99|doi=10.1016/j.fbr.2013.09.001}}</ref> Often, Fungi fail to fit into a defined exploration type, falling instead along a gradient. Exploration type also fails to take into account other aspects of hyphal morphology, such as the extent to which hyphae cross into deeper [[soil horizons]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Genney|first=D.R.|author2=Anderson, I. C. |author3=Alexander, I. J. |title=Fine-scale distribution of pine ectomycorrhizas and their extramatrical mycelium.|journal=The New Phytologist|year=2006|volume=170|issue=2|pages=381–90|doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2006.01669.x}}</ref>
Field studies have shown that extramatrical mycelium is more likely to proliferate in [[mineral soil]]s than in [[organic material]], and may be particularly absent in fresh [[leaf litter]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lindahl|first=B.D.|author2=Ihrmark, K. |author3=Boberg, J. |author4=Trumbore, S. E. |author5=Högberg, P. |author6=Stenlid, J. |author7=Finlay, R. D. |title=Spatial separation of litter decomposition and mycorrhizal nitrogen uptake in a boreal forest.|journal=New Phytologist|year=2007|volume=173|issue=3|pages=611–20|doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2006.01936.x |pmid=17244056}}</ref> However, the presence of different ectomycorrhizal groups in different [[soil horizons]] suggest that different groups have evolved specialized [[niche separation]], possibly attributable to exploration type.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Landeweert|first=R.|author2=Leeflang, P. |author3=Kuyper, T. W. |author4=Hoffland, E. |author5=Rosling, A. |author6=Wernars, K. |author7=Smit, E. |title=Molecular identification of ectomycorrhizal mycelium in soil horizons.|journal=Applied and Environmental Microbiology|year=2003|volume=69|issue=1|pages=327–33|pmc=152382 |pmid=12514012 |doi=10.1128/aem.69.1.327-333.2003}}</ref>
== Ecological implications ==
=== Community assembly ===
[[File:Laccaria, DOE.jpg|thumbnail|left|Ectomycorrhizal Laccaria fruit bodies in forest community]] Because ectomycorrhizas are small and possess a limited contact area with the surrounding soil, the presence of extramatrical hyphae significantly increases the [[surface area]] in contact with the surrounding environment. Increased surface area means greater access to necessary nutrient sources. Additionally, the presence of rhizomorphs or [[mycelial cords]], can act comparably to [[xylem]] tissue in plants, where hollow tubes of vessel hyphae shuttle water and [[solubilized]] nutrients over long distances.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Cairney|first=J. W. G.|title=Translocation of solutes in ectomycorrhizal and saprotrophic rhizomorphs.|journal=Mycological Research|year=1992|volume=96|issue=2|pages=135–141|doi=10.1016/S0953-7562(09)80928-3}}</ref> The abundance and spatial distribution of host root tips in the [[rhizosphere]] is an important factor mediating ectomycorrhizal [[Community (ecology)|community assembly]]. Root density may select for the exploration types best suited for a given root spacing. In [[Pine]] systems, Fungi that display short-distance exploration types are less able to colonize new roots spaced far from the mycorrhiza, and long-distance types dominate areas of low root density. Conversely, short-distance exploration types tend to dominate areas of high root density where decreased carbon expenditure makes them more competitive than long-distance species.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Peay|first=K. G|author2=Kennedy, P. G. |author3=Bruns, T. D. |title=Rethinking ectomycorrhizal succession: are root density and hyphal exploration types drivers of spatial and temporal zonation?|journal=Fungal Ecology|year=2011|volume=4|issue=3|pages=233–240|doi=10.1016/j.funeco.2010.09.010}}</ref> The growth of extramatrical mycelium has a direct effect on the mutualistic nutrient trading between ectomycorrhizal fungi and their hosts. Increased hyphal occupation of the soil allows the fungus to take greater advantage of water and nutrients otherwise inaccessible to plant roots and to more efficiently transport these resources back to the plant. Conversely, the increased costs in carbon allocation associated with supporting a fungal partner with an extensive mycelial system presents a number of questions related to the [[costs and benefits]] of ectomycorrhizal mutualism.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Weigt|first=R. B.|author2=Raidl, S. |author3=Verma, R. |author4=Agerer, R. |title=Exploration type-specific standard values of extramatrical mycelium – a step towards quantifying ectomycorrhizal space occupation and biomass in natural soil.|journal=Mycological Progress|year=2011|volume=11|issue=1|pages=287–297|doi=10.1007/s11557-011-0750-5}}</ref>
=== Carbon cycling ===
Although there is evidence that certain species of mycorrhizal fungi may obtain at least a portion of their carbon via [[saprotrophic nutrition]],<ref>{{cite journal|last=Talbot|first=J.M.|author2=Allison, S. D. |author3=Treseder, K. K. |title=Decomposers in disguise: mycorrhizal fungi as regulators of soil C dynamics in ecosystems under global change.|journal=Functional Ecology|year=2008|volume=22|issue=6|pages=955–963|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2435.2008.01402.x}}</ref> the bulk of mycorrhizal carbon acquisition happens by way of trading for host-derived [[Photosynthate|photosynthetic products]]. Mycorrhizal systems represent a major [[carbon sink]]. Laboratory studies predict that around 23% of plant-derived carbon is allocated to extrametrical mycelium,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rygiewicz|first=P.T.|author2=Andersen, C. P.|title=Mycorrhizae alter quality and quantity of carbon allocated below ground.|journal=Nature|year=1994|volume=369|issue=6475|pages=58–60|doi=10.1038/369058a0}}</ref> although an estimated 15-30% of this is lost to fungal respiration.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hasselquist|first=N.J.|author2=Vargas, R. |author3=Allen, M. F. |title=Using soil sensing technology to examine interactions and controls between ectomycorrhizal growth and environmental factors on soil CO<sub>2</sub> dynamics.|journal=Plant and Soil|year=2009|volume=331|issue=1–2|pages=17–29|doi=10.1007/s11104-009-0183-y}}</ref><ref name="HeinemeyerHartley2007">{{cite journal|last1=Heinemeyer|first1=Andreas|last2=Hartley|first2=Iain P.|last3=Evans|first3=Sam P.|last4=Carreira De La Fuente|first4=José A.|last5=Ineson|first5=Phil|title=Forest soil CO2flux: uncovering the contribution and environmental responses of ectomycorrhizas|journal=Global Change Biology|volume=13|issue=8|year=2007|pages=1786–1797|issn=1354-1013|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2486.2007.01383.x}}</ref> Carbon allocation is distributed unequally to extramatrical mycelium depending on fungal taxa, nutrient availability, and the age of the associated mycorrhizas.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rosling|first=A.|author2=Lindahl, B. D. |author3=Finlay, R. D. |title=Carbon allocation to ectomycorrhizal roots and mycelium colonising different mineral substrates.|journal=New Phytologist|year=2004|volume=162|issue=3|pages=795–802|doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2004.01080.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Wu|first=B.|author2=Nara, K. |author3=Hogetsu, T. |title=Spatiotemporal transfer of carbon-14-labelled photosynthate from ectomycorrhizal Pinus densiflora seedlings to extraradical mycelia.|journal=Mycorrhiza|year=2002|volume=12|issue=2|pages=83–88|doi=10.1007/s00572-001-0157-2}}</ref> Much of the carbon allocated to extramatrical mycelium accumulates as fungal [[biomass]], making up an estimated one-third of the total [[microbial]] biomass and one-half of the total [[dissolved organic carbon]] in some forest soils.<ref name="Högberg 2002 791–795"/> Carbon also supports the production of [[sporocarp (fungi)|sporocarp]]s and [[sclerotia]], with various taxa investing differentially in these structures rather than in the proliferation of extramatrical mycelium. Carbon acquisition also goes toward the production of fungal exudates. Extramatrical hyphae excrete a range of compounds into the soil matrix, accounting for as much as 40% of total carbon usage.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Fransson|first=P.M.A.|author2=Anderson, I. C. |author3=Alexander, I. J. |title=Ectomycorrhizal fungi in culture respond differently to increased carbon availability.|journal=Microbiology Ecology|year=2007|volume=61|issue=1|pages=246–57|doi=10.1111/j.1574-6941.2007.00343.x}}</ref> These exudates are released primarily at the growing front, and are used in functions such as [[mineralization (soil)|mineralization]] and [[homeostasis]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Sun|first=Y.P.|author2=Unestam, T. |author3=Lucas, S. D. |author4=Johanson, K. J. |author5=Kenne, L. |author6=Finlay, R. |title=Exudation-reabsorption in a mycorrhizal fungus, the dynamic interface for interaction with soil and soil microorganisms.|journal=Mycorrhiza|year=1999|volume=9|issue=3|pages=137–144|doi=10.1007/s005720050298}}</ref>
Many researchers have attempted projections of the role that extramatrical mycelium may play in [[carbon sequestration]]. Although estimates of the life span of individual ectomycorrhizas very considerably, turnover is generally considered on a scale of months. [[File:Ectomycorrhizae002.jpg|thumbnail|right|Cortinarius ectomycorrhizas and extramatrical mycelium on ''Pseudotsuga menziesii'' roots]]After death, the presence ectomycorrhizas on root tips, may increase the rate of root [[decomposition]] for some [[Taxonomy (biology)|fungal taxa]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Koide|first=R.T.|author2=Fernandez, C. W. |author3=Peoples, M. S. |title=Can ectomycorrhizal colonization of Pinus resinosa roots affect their decomposition?|journal=New Phytologist|year=2011|volume=191|issue=2|pages=508–14|doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2011.03694.x|pmid=21418224}}</ref> Besides host plant death and mycorrhizal turnover, rates of carbon sequestration may also be affected by disturbances in the soil, which cause sections of the extramatrical mycelium to become severed from the host plant. Such disturbances, such as those caused by animal disruption, [[mycophagous]] invertebrates or habitat destruction, may have a notable impact on turnover rates. These variables make it difficult to estimate the turnover rates of mycorrhizal biomass in forest soils and the relative contribution of extramatrical mycelium to carbon sequestration.
=== Mycelial networks ===
The presence of long-distance extramatrical hyphae may affect forest health via the formation of common mycelial networks, in which hyphal connections form between plant hosts and can facilitate the transfer of carbon and nutrients between hosts.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Selosse|first=M.A.|author2=Richard, F. |author3=He, X. |author4=Simard, S. W. |title=Mycorrhizal networks: des liaisons dangereuses?|journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution|year=2006|doi=10.1016/j.tree.2006.07.003 |pmid=16843567 |volume=21 |issue=11 |pages=621–8}}</ref> Mycelial networks may also be responsible for facilitating the transport of [[allelopathic]] chemicals from the supplying plant directly to the rhizosphere of other plants.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Barto|first=E.K.|author2=Hilker, M. |author3=Müller, F. |author4=Mohney, B. K. |author5=Weidenhamer, J. D. |author6=Rillig, M. C. |title=The fungal fast lane: common mycorrhizal networks extend bioactive zones of allelochemicals in soils.|journal=PLOS ONE|year=2011|volume=6|issue=11|pages=e27195.|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0027195 |pmid=22110615 |pmc=3215695}}</ref> Ectomycorrhizal fungi increase [[primary production]] in host plants, with [[Trophic level|multi trophic]] effects. In this way, extramatrical mycelium is important to the maintenance of soil [[food webs]],<ref name="Pollierer 2007 729–36"/> supplying a significant nutritive source to invertebrates and [[microorganisms]].
== Mineral access ==
=== Enzyme production ===
The [[enzymatic activity|enzymatic activities]] of ectomycorrhizal fungi are highly variable between species. These differences are correlated with exploration type (particularly the presence or absence of rhizomorphs) rather than lineage or host association- suggesting that similar morphologies of extraradical mycelium are an example of [[convergent evolution]].<ref name="TedersooNaadel2012"/> Differences in [[enzymatic activity]], and hence the ability to degrade [[organic compounds]] dictate fungal nutrient access, with wide ranging ecological implications.
=== Phosphorus ===
Because diverse ectomycorrhizal fungal taxa differ greatly in their [[metabolic activity]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Trocha, L. K.|first=L. K.|author2=Mucha, J. |author3=Eissenstat, D. M. |author4=Reich, P. B. |author5=Oleksyn, J. |title=Ectomycorrhizal identity determines respiration and concentrations of nitrogen and non-structural carbohydrates in root tips: a test using Pinus sylvestris and Quercus robur saplings.|journal=Tree Physiology|year=2010|volume=30|issue=5|pages=648–54|doi=10.1093/treephys/tpq014}}</ref> they also often differ in their capacity to trade nutrients with their hosts.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Burgess|first=T. I.|author2=Malajczuk, N. |author3=Grove, T. S. |title=The ability of 16 ectomycorrhizal fungi to increase growth and phosphorus uptake of Eucalyptus globulus Labill. and E. diversicolor F. Muell.|journal=Plant and Soil|year=1993|volume=153|issue=2|pages=155–164|doi=10.1007/BF00012988}}</ref> Phosphorus acquisition by mycorrhizal fungi, and the subsequent transfer to plant hosts, is thought to be one of the main functions of ectomycorrhizal symbiosis. Extramatrical mycelium is the site of collection for phosphorus within the soil system. This relationship is so strong that starving host plants of phosphorus is known to increase the growth of extramatrical mycelium tenfold.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wallander|first=H.|author2=Nylund, J. E.|title=Effects of excess nitrogen and phosphorus starvation on the extramatrical mycelium of ectomycorrhizas of Pinus sylvestris L.|journal=New Phytologist|year=1992|volume=120|issue=4|pages=495–503|doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.1992.tb01798.x}}</ref>
=== Nitrogen ===
Recently, [[Isotope|Isotopic]] studies have been used to investigate relative trading between ectomycorrhizal fungi and plant hosts and to assess the relative importance of exploration type on nutrient trading ability. <sup>15</sup>N values are elevated in ectomycorrhizal Fungi and depleted in fungal hosts, as a result of nutrient trading.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hogberg|first=P.|author2=Hogberg, M. N. |author3=Quist, M. E. |author4=Ekblad, A. |author5=Nasholm, T. |title=Nitrogen isotope fractionation during nitrogen uptake by ectomycorrhizal and non-mycorrhizal Pinus sylvestris.|journal=New Phytologist|year=1999|volume=142|issue=3|pages=569–576|doi=10.1046/j.1469-8137.1999.00404.x}}</ref> Fungal species with exploration types producing greater amounts of extraradical mycelium are known to accumulate greater amounts <sup>15</sup>N <ref name="TedersooNaadel2012"/><ref>{{cite journal|last=Hobbie|first=E.A.|author2=Agerer, R.|title=Nitrogen isotopes in ectomycorrhizal sporocarps correspond to belowground exploration types|journal=Plant and Soil|year=2009|volume=327|issue=1–2|pages=71–83|doi=10.1007/s11104-009-0032-z}}</ref> in both root tips and fruit bodies, a phenomenon partially attributed to higher levels of N cycling within these species.
== Assessment methods ==
[[File:Amanita phalloides.R.H. 17.jpg|thumbnail|right| ''Amanita phalloides'' mycelium]] Determining the [[longevity]] of extramatrical mycelium is difficult, and estimates range from just a few months to several years. Turnover rates are assessed in a variety of ways including direct observation and <sup>14</sup>[[Carbon dating|C dating]]. Such estimates are an important variable in calculating the contribution that ectomycorrhizal fungi have to [[carbon sequestration]].<ref name="Cairney 2012">{{cite journal|last=Cairney|first=J. W. G|title=Extramatrical mycelia of ectomycorrhizal fungi as moderators of carbon dynamics in forest soil.|journal=Soil Biology and Biochemistry.|year=2012|doi=10.1016/j.soilbio.2011.12.029|volume=47|pages=198–208}}</ref> In order to differentiate ectomycorrhizal mycelium from the mycelium of [[Saprotrophic nutrition|saprotrophic fungi]], biomass estimates are often done by [[ergosterol]] or phospholipid fatty acid analysis, or by using sand-filled bags, which are likely to be avoided by saprotrophic fungi because they lack [[organic matter]].<ref name="Cairney 2012"/> Detailed morphological characterization of exploration type has been defined for over 550 different ectomycorrhizal species and are compiled in [[Deemy Database|www. deemy. de]]. Due to the difficulty in classifying exploration types of intermediate forms, other metrics have been proposed to qualify and quantify the growth of extramatrical mycelium, including Specific Actual/Potential Mycelium Space Occupation and Specific Extramatrical Mycelial Length<ref>{{cite journal|last=Weigt|first=R.B.|author2=Raidl, S. |author3=Verma, R. |author4=Agerer, R. |title=Exploration type-specific standard values of extramatrical mycelium – a step towards quantifying ectomycorrhizal space occupation and biomass in natural soil.|journal=Mycological Progress|year=2011|volume=11|issue=1|pages=287–297|doi=10.1007/s11557-011-0750-5}}</ref> which attempt to account for the contributions of mycelial [[density]], [[surface area]] and total [[biomass]].

'''Kids Code Jeunesse''' (KCJ) is a Canadian not for profit organization<ref name="Hanna">{{cite web |last1=Hanna |first1=Chris |title=Learning code a key ability for kids |url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/technology/Montreal+Diary+Learning+code+ability+kids/9372874/story.html |website=Montreal Gazette |accessdate=26 June 2018 |date=10 January 2014}}</ref> based in [[Montreal, Quebec]]<ref name="Marchal">{{cite web |last1=Marchal |first1=Mathias |title=Montreal organization receives $ 6M to introduce kids to coding|url=http://journalmetro.com/actualites/montreal/1365366/un-organisme-de-montreal-recoit-6m-pour-initier-les-enfants-au-codage/ |website=Journal Metro |publisher=Transcontinental Média |accessdate=10 July 2018 |date=24 January 2018}}</ref> which helps children in Canada have an opportunity to learn computational thinking through code.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lepage |first1=Ninon Louise |title=Teach programming with the support of Kids Code Jeunesse |url=https://ecolebranchee.com/2016/10/06/enseigner-programmation-kids-code-jeunesse/ |website=École branchée |accessdate=12 July 2018 |date=6 October 2016}}</ref> This organization, founded in 2013 by Kate Arthur,<ref name="Hanna" /> is primarily used by children, teachers, and parents with the skills needed for the modern society.<ref name="Mason">{{cite web |last1=Mason |first1=Quinn |title=Kids Code Jeunesse to receive major funding from $50 million CanCode program |url=http://www.montrealintechnology.com/kids-code-jeunesse-one-of-charities-to-receive-major-funding-from-50-million-cancode-program/ |website=MTL in Tech |accessdate=26 June 2018 |date=22 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="Brookfield">{{cite book |last1=Huynh |first1=Annalise |last2=Malli |first2=Nisa |title=Levelling Up: The Quest for Digital Literacy |date=June 2018 |publisher=Brookfield institute for innovation + entrepreneurship |isbn=978-1-926769-90-5 |pages=72 |url=http://brookfieldinstitute.ca/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/Level-Up-report-FINAL-online.pdf}}</ref> KCJ wants more creatures than producers.<ref name="Saint-Amant-Ringuette">{{cite web |last1=Saint-Amant-Ringuette |first1=Alexane |title=Code Create Educate: Inspire the Next Generation of Creators Starts in the Classroom |url=https://ecolebranchee.com/2018/03/20/coder-creer-eduquer-inspirer-prochaine-generation-de-createurs-canadiens-debute-salle-de-classe/ |website=École Branchée |date=20 March 2018}}</ref> The intent is not to replace existing courses with computer science, but rather complement them with coding.<ref name="Hanna" /> Kids Code Jeunesse uses intuitive, open source, free tools such as [[Scratch (programming language)|Scratch]] and Trinket.<ref>{{cite web |title=Hour of Code aims to demystify computer programming in 1 hour |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/hour-of-code-montreal-activities-1.3354654 |website=CBC News |date=7 December 2015}}</ref> Its education materials are developed for children aged 5 to 12 years old.<ref name="Marchal" /> By targeting a younger age group, KCJ is helping boost the children's abilities in communication, collaboration, problem-solving, and creative thinking.<ref name="Brookfield" />
KCJ has partnered with local,<ref>{{cite web |title=Ubisoft Codex and Kids Youth Code at Chromatic Kids|url=https://montreal.ubisoft.com/fr/ubisoft-codex-x-kids-code-jeunesse-a-chromatic-kids/ |website=Ubisoft Montreal |date=31 May 2018}}</ref> national,<ref name="Terri Coles">{{cite web |last1=Coles |first1=Terri |title=Newfoundland teachers learn coding — and what it could mean for the next generation |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/coding-teachers-classroom-create-code-teach-1.4751366 |website=CBC News |accessdate=23 July 2018 |date=22 July 2018}}</ref> and international partners<ref>{{cite web |last1=Tung |first1=Liam |title=BBC's Raspberry Pi Zero rival heads to Canada in 100,000 bulk order |url=https://www.zdnet.com/article/bbcs-raspberry-pi-zero-rival-heads-to-canada-in-100000-bulk-order/ |website=ZDNet |accessdate=18 July 2018 |date=22 February 2018}}</ref> in order to raise awareness across Canada in both official languages.<ref name="Hanna" />
==Projects==
===Code Club=== In 2016, in partnership with [[Code Club|Code Club U.K.]], KCJ licensed the rights to Code Club Canada, which runs volunteer-led Code Clubs for free across Canada. There are now over 150 Code Clubs registered, throughout every province and territory.<ref name="Mason" /> These clubs, set up at schools, libraries and community centers for a minimum of 8 weeks host free coding activities for children aged 7-12.
===Code Create Teach=== In 2016, Kids Code Jeunesse, in partnership with Lighthouse Labs,<ref name="Mason" /> embarked on a national campaign to inspire teachers to incorporate the basics of coding and computational thinking into their classrooms.<ref name="Terri Coles" /> From April to December 2018, KCJ will be hosting free, full-day Code Create Teach workshops which will provide K-12 educators with the tools to help them teach their students how to experiment with technology.<ref name="Galang" /> Two workshops are planned for each Canadian province and territory allowing KCJ to reach over 1500 teachers. During the workshops, KCJ instructors provide tips and guidelines to bring coding into the classroom, as well as combine unplugged activities with hands-on coding activities. These methods gives attendees the opportunity to connect with other teachers in purposeful and learner-driven way.<ref name="Saint-Amant-Ringuette" /> Following the Code Create Teach workshops, each teacher is given a free classroom kit of [[Micro Bit|micro:bits]], a pocket-sized programmable microcontroller designed to make learning and teaching code easy and fun.<ref name="Galang">{{cite web |last1=Galang |first1=Jessica |title=LIGHTHOUSE LABS AND KIDS CODE JEUNESSE LAUNCH PROGRAM TO HELP TEACHERS LEARN TO CODE |url=https://betakit.com/lighthouse-labs-and-kids-code-jeunesse-launch-program-to-equip-teachers-with-coding-knowledge/ |website=Betakit |accessdate=20 July 2018 |date=20 March 2018}}</ref>
===Code MTL=== In 2017, KCJ was contracted for CodeMTL, a project designed to KCJs coding workshops to over 65 schools in the Commission Scolaire de Montréal, Quebec's largest school board.<ref name="Mason" />
===CanCode=== In January 2018, the Honourable Navdeep Bains, Canada’s Minister of Innovation, Science and Economic Development announced that Kids Code Jeunesse was one the recipients of the inaugural CanCode program. This program is part of the Canadian Government's Innovation and Skills Plan which has the stated intention to invest $50 million by March 2019 to increase the opportunities for children and teachers to master digital skills. With the funds received, Kids Code Jeunesse has been able to extend the training it provides to Canada's youth and aims to support over 70,000 children and 2000 teachers.<ref name="Mason" />
